entry.title: Bitacora
entry.content:
This is my bitacora. Some conventions used here ( üìÜ : todo , üö∂ :‚Äç reading , ‚úçÔ∏è : writing , ‚ùì : question and üèÅ : goal, and üîß :fixing).

Research topics

The goals and topics can change along the time, nowadays I‚Äôm working on the following.

(homotopy) type theory

  • pathovers: proofs finished, fixing the writing ‚úçÔ∏è
  • circle equivalences: removing a postulate ‚úçÔ∏è
  • mini-hott: a mini hott library for Agda ‚úçÔ∏è
  • ‚ùì A HIT can be seen as graph where
    • each point-constructor is a node,
    • each path-constructor is an edge

‚ùì By changing the direction of one edge, can we get another HIT equivalent ?

Formal graph theory

  • üö∂ What is a good characterization for planar graphs. What really does good means? good from the verification point of view or the most suitable to use dependent type theory, or HoTT‚ùì

    When when want to have a property like isPlanar such that it is not a proposition in the HoTT context.

Meetings

Showing the most recent to the oldest.

2018-09-14

With H√•kon:

  • HoTT stuff: we review the lemmas for the flattening lemma. We went through Lemma 6.12.1 to Lemma 6.12.7.
  • Graphs: I commented a little bit the MacLane‚Äôs cycle-space and Tutte‚Äôs theorem which relies on the idea of contractible version of the graphs to use later the Kuratowski theorem.

With Marc:

  • Working on the circle article to remove the postulated lemmas

2018-09-07

With H√•kon:

  • We sketch briefly alga or the algebra of graphs described in (\cite{Mokhov2017}).
  • We review the inductive definition for graphs in (Tammet, 1996), we wanted to have a predicate like
  • H√•kon also pointed out MacLane‚Äôs planar graph characterization to review in future sessions.

With Marc:

  • Making some improvements to Pathovers‚Äô article.

Formalization of graphs

  • Papers relevant to formalizations of graphs:

Inductive definitions. Using inductive definitions allows us to have for free an inductive principle to prove properties. One issue using these kind of definitions is the difficulty that represents to reason about their constructions. Which it‚Äôs taking care of the order of the step in the construction. So, how can we have a relation between these constructions in such a away, a graph can be obtained by (homotopic?) constructions?.

(Yamamoto, Nishizaki, Hagiya, & Toda, 1995)

In this paper, the authors show as their main result, the formalization of the Euler formula. To achieve this they define inductively planar graphs by using the notion of cycles. The formalization was done in HOL.

(Bauer & Nipkow, 2002)

This paper is about the formalization of the Five-Colour theorem. In this, the authors show an inductive definition for near triangulations in order to define inductively planar graphs. This definition has three constructors:

Some results:

  • Any planar graph has at least a vertex of at least degree less or equals five.
  • Idem for near triangulations.

(Bauer, 2005)

Continuing with near triangulations, Bauer in this thesis has an extra constructor for it.

He ends up Chapter 2 with the following summary of formalizations of planar graphs.

Triangles vs. Polygons: The definition using triangles is by far eas- ier. This simplifies proofs about the construction. If faces of arbi- trary length can be added, the graph modifications and proofs about those are more complex. On the other hand, a formalization based on triangles requires operations to delete edges in order to construct non-triangular graphs, which complicates a verification. Directed

(Mokhov, Andrey, Mokhov, & Andrey, 2017)

Alga. Missing description.

Questions and Related blog post

  • üìÜ https://mathoverflow.net/questions/278015/number-of-non-equivalent-graph-embeddings
  • üìÜ https://mathoverflow.net/questions/134010/embeddings-of-graphs-into-surfaces?rq=1
  • üìÜ Ricard Williams, Noam Zeilberger and Peter Heinig: https://goo.gl/xrn9im
  • üìÜ Algebraic proof of Five-Color Theorem using chromatic polynomials by Birkhoff and Lewis in 1946
  • üìÜ Why are planar graphs so exceptional?
  • üìÜ Kalai‚Äôs Post
  • üìÜ Generalizations of Planar Graphs
entry.summary: This is my bitacora. Some conventions used here ( üìÜ : todo , üö∂ :‚Äç reading , ‚úçÔ∏è : writing , ‚ùì : question and üèÅ : goal, and üîß :fixing).

entry.title: INF234
entry.content:
Just the agenda for INF234 at UiB. The book is (Dasgupta & Papadimitriou, 2006).

2018-08-21

  • Introduction and Syllabus
  • Big-Oh rules

Exercise set 1 - for the exercise sessions on August 27-30

  • http://dm.compsciclub.ru/app/quiz-opposite-colors
  • http://dm.compsciclub.ru/app/quiz-clock-game
  • http://dm.compsciclub.ru/app/quiz-hanoi-towers
  • Exercise 0.1.
  • Exercise 0.2.
  • Exercise 0.3.
  • Exercise 2.3. Recurrence substitution.
  • Exercise 2.4. Master theorem.

2018-08-24

  • Big-Oh rules
  • Omega, and small big-oh.
  • Divide and Conquer
    • Sorting problem. Runtime analysis.
    • T(n) = a T(n/b) + O(n^a) where a is the branching factor, b is the size of the problems.
    • Geometric series: 1 + r + r^2 + ‚Ä¶ + r^t = (1 - r^(t+1))/(1 - r)
      • if r < 1, the sums tends to be 1 / (1 - r).
    • MergeSort algorithm

2018-08-31

  • Master Theorem (and proof) (some logarithms rules viewed)

2018-09-03

  • Review the formulation of the master algorithm
  • Divide & conquer algorithm to find the median of an array of integers.
  • Selection pivot algorithm to improve the median selection algorithm.
    • https://brilliant.org/wiki/median-finding-algorithm/
  • Exercise 2.5. Master Theorem
  • Exercise 2.12. Recurrence substitution.
  • Exercise 2.14. Just use Mergesort and remove naively the duplicates
  • Exercise 2.13. Catalan Numbers (Nice one).

If is the number of full binary trees with exactly n vertices, then, we can compute recursively the solution by following that‚Äôs equal to

where, when k is odd and .

2018-09-07

  • Class was Introduction to Graphs, DFS, explore method, pre and post numbers

  • Exercise 2.20.
    • Algorithm: counting sort.
    • Why not \Omega(nlog n)? because is not based on comparisons.
  • Exercise 2.23.
    • a) ``` def Majority(A): if len(A) == 1: return A[0] half1 = Majority(first half) half2 = Majority(second half) check half1 in all the array to be the majority element if it‚Äôs not check with half2 in all the array else: there is no majority element
    - b) Algorithm: [MJRTY - A Fast Majority Vote Algorithm](https://www.cs.utexas.edu/~moore/best-ideas/mjrty/example.html#step13)

  - [x] Exercise 3.1: Just perform a DFS
  - [ ] Exercise 3.2
    ![](/assets/png-images/2018-08-24-learning-inf234-850e4ac8.png)

  - [ ] Exercise 3.3.
    Kahn' Topological Sort algorithm:
    ![](/assets/png-images/2018-08-24-learning-inf234-6fa99409.png)
    - Sources (A,B) and the sinks (G, H)
    - How many toposorts the graph has? 8.

## 2018-09-10

  - DFS, DFS tree, DFS forest construction in O(n + m) where n is #vertices and m is #edges
    - üë®‚Äçüéì When drawing always make the arrows (dotted) to point out the exploration traces.
    - tree edges are the first edges in the DFS from parent to child, if the child
    is already discovered then a edge parent-child becomes a forward edge.
  - Connected Component in O(n+m):
    - Run a DFS for all vertices, if a vertex is unvisited the there is a component
    with that vertex, and continue with next vertex.
  - **Check the type of edges**:

  Review the pre/post numbers for each vertex in the exploration of the graph:
For instance: `pre(u) < pre(v) < post(v) < post(u)`:
![](/assets/png-images/2018-08-24-learning-inf234-05b9e04d.png)

And then we have:

![](/assets/png-images/2018-08-24-learning-inf234-64d0ba82.png)

  - DAG (Directed acyclic graphs) ( a cycle has not repeated points)

## 2018-09-14
  - [Tarjan' Strongly connected component algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tarjan%27s_strongly_connected_components_algorithm)
  - [Kosaraju' Strongly connected component algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosaraju%27s_algorithm)
    - meta graph (DFS too)

Kosaraju‚Äôs Algorithm:

  1. For each vertex u of the graph, mark u as unvisited. Let L be empty.
  2. For each vertex u of the graph do Visit(u), where Visit(u) is the recursive subroutine: If u is unvisited then:
    • Mark u as visited.
    • For each out-neighbour v of u, do Visit(v).
    • Prepend u to L. Otherwise do nothing.
  3. For each element u of L in order, do Assign(u,u) where Assign(u,root) is the recursive subroutine: If u has not been assigned to a component then:
    • Assign u as belonging to the component whose root is root.
    • For each in-neighbour v of u, do Assign(v,root). Otherwise do nothing. ```

2018-09-17

  • BFS (breath-first search) correctness of the algorithm
  • Correctness of Dijkstra Algorithm
  • Run the Dijkstra algorithm on paper for a small example

entry.title: Simple Typed Lambda Calculus In Agda

link.title: Simple Typed Lambda Calculus In Agda

entry.content:
We present a formalisation of the syntax in Agda for the Simple Typed Lambda Calculus (STLC) with some of its properties and the description of the type-checking for this type system. We refactor the implementation by @gergoerdi for this calculus, in particular the Scopecheck and Typecheck module.

The following source code was tested with:

  • Agda v2.5.4
  • Agda Standard Library v0.16

The original content was firstly exposed in the seminar of logic at Universidad EAFIT.

  • Slides.
  • Repository: https://github.com/jonaprieto/stlctalk.
-- Agda Imports

open import Data.String using (String)
open import Relation.Nullary.Decidable using (False)
open import Relation.Binary using (IsDecEquivalence)
open import Relation.Binary.PropositionalEquality using (_‚â°_; subst)

Syntax

First definition of Typed Lambda Calculus

Name : Set
Name = String

module Syntax (Type : Set) where

  data Formal : Set where
    _‚à∂_ : Name ‚Üí Type ‚Üí Formal

  data Expr : Set where
    var : Name   ‚Üí Expr
    lam : Formal ‚Üí Expr ‚Üí Expr
    _‚àô_ : Expr   ‚Üí Expr ‚Üí Expr

  infixl 20 _‚àô_

Examples

private
    postulate
      A : Type

    x = var "x"
    y = var "y"
    z = var "z"

    -- Œª(x:A).x
    I : Expr
    I = lam ("x" ‚à∂ A) x

    -- Œª(x,y:A).x
    K : Expr
    K = lam ("x" ‚à∂ A) (lam ("y" ‚à∂ A) x)

    -- Œª(x,y,z:A).xz(yz)
    S : Expr
    S =
      lam ("x" ‚à∂ A)
        (lam ("y" ‚à∂ A)
          (lam ("z" ‚à∂ A)
            ((x ‚àô z) ‚àô (y ‚àô z))))

Bound

Lambda terms using De Bruijn indexes.

module Bound (Type : Set) where

  open import Data.Nat    hiding (_‚âü_)
  open import Data.Fin    using (Fin; #_; suc)
  open import Data.String using (_‚âü_)
  open import Data.Vec    using (Vec; _‚à∑_; [])

  module S = Syntax Type
  open S hiding (Expr; module Expr) public

Syntax using indexes.

data Expr (n : ‚Ñï) : Set where
    var : Fin n  ‚Üí Expr n
    lam : Type   ‚Üí Expr (suc n) ‚Üí Expr n
    _‚àô_ : Expr n ‚Üí Expr n       ‚Üí Expr n

  infixl 20 _‚àô_

  -- The context for variables: vector of fixed length
  -- of strings.
  Binder : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Set
  Binder = Vec Name

  _,_ : ‚àÄ {n} ‚Üí Binder n ‚Üí Name ‚Üí Binder (suc n)
  Œì , x = x ‚à∑ Œì
  infixl 5 _,_

  data _‚ä¢_‚áù_ : ‚àÄ {n} ‚Üí Binder n ‚Üí S.Expr ‚Üí Expr n ‚Üí Set where
    var-zero
      : ‚àÄ {n x} {Œì : Binder n}
      ---------------------------
      ‚Üí Œì , x ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù var (# 0)

    var-suc
      : ‚àÄ {n x y k} {Œì : Binder n} {p : False (x ‚âü y)}
      ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù var k
      -----------------------------
      ‚Üí Œì , y ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù var (suc k)

    lam
      : ‚àÄ {n x A t t'} {Œì : Binder n}
      ‚Üí Œì , x ‚ä¢ t ‚áù t'
      ------------------------------
      ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ lam (x ‚à∂ A) t ‚áù lam A t'

    _‚àô_
      : ‚àÄ {n t‚ÇÅ t‚ÇÅ' t‚ÇÇ t‚ÇÇ'} {Œì : Binder n}
      ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚áù t‚ÇÅ'
      ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÇ ‚áù t‚ÇÇ'
      -------------------------
      ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚áù t‚ÇÅ' ‚àô t‚ÇÇ'
  infixl 3 _‚ä¢_‚áù_

Examples

private
    ‚àÖ : Binder 0
    ‚àÖ = []

    Œì : Binder 2
    Œì = [] , "x" , "y"

    e1 : Œì ‚ä¢ var "x" ‚áù var (# 1)
    e1 = var-suc var-zero

    postulate A : Type

    I : [] ‚ä¢ lam ("x" ‚à∂ A) (var "x")
           ‚áù lam A (var (# 0))
    I = lam var-zero

    K : [] ‚ä¢ lam ("x" ‚à∂ A) (lam ("y" ‚à∂ A) (var "x"))
           ‚áù lam A (lam A (var (# 1)))
    K = lam (lam (var-suc var-zero))

    K‚ÇÇ : [] ‚ä¢ lam ("x" ‚à∂ A) (lam ("y" ‚à∂ A) (var "y"))
            ‚áù lam A (lam A (var (# 0)))
    K‚ÇÇ = lam (lam var-zero)

    P : Œì ‚ä¢ lam ("x" ‚à∂ A) (lam ("y" ‚à∂ A) (lam ("z" ‚à∂ A) (var "x")))
           ‚áù lam A (lam A (lam A (var (# 2))))
    P = lam (lam (lam (var-suc (var-suc var-zero))))

Scopecheck

Check representation of Œª-terms using de Bruijn indexes. Get a Œª-term using de Bruijn indexes by given a Œª-term with names.

-- ‚àÉ-syntax and ‚àÑ-syntax

open import Data.Product hiding (‚àÉ-syntax; ‚àÑ-syntax) renaming (_,_ to _-by-_)
open import Data.Product using (‚àÉ; ‚àÑ)

‚àÉ-syntax : ‚àÄ {a b} {A : Set a} ‚Üí (A ‚Üí Set b) ‚Üí Set _
‚àÉ-syntax = ‚àÉ
syntax ‚àÉ-syntax (Œª x ‚Üí B) = ‚àÉ[ x ] B

‚àÑ-syntax : ‚àÄ {a b} {A : Set a} ‚Üí (A ‚Üí Set b) ‚Üí Set _
‚àÑ-syntax = ‚àÑ
syntax ‚àÑ-syntax (Œª x ‚Üí B) = ‚àÑ[ x ] B
module Scopecheck (Type : Set) where

  open Bound Type public

  open import Data.Fin     using (Fin; suc; #_)
  open import Data.Nat     hiding (_‚âü_)
  open import Data.String  using (_‚âü_)
  open import Data.Sum     using (_‚äé_; inj‚ÇÅ ; inj‚ÇÇ)
  open import Data.Vec     using (Vec; []; _‚à∑_)

  open import Function     using (_$_)

  open import Relation.Binary.PropositionalEquality using (_‚â°_; refl; subst)
  open import Relation.Nullary                      using (Dec; no; yes)
  open import Relation.Nullary.Decidable
    using (fromWitnessFalse; fromWitness; toWitness; True)
name-dec
    : ‚àÄ {n} {Œì : Binder n} {x y : Name} {t : Expr (suc n)}
    ‚Üí Œì , y ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù t
    ----------------------------------
    ‚Üí x ‚â° y ‚äé ‚àÉ[ t‚Ä≤ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù t‚Ä≤)

  name-dec var-zero = inj‚ÇÅ refl
  name-dec {t = var (suc k)} (var-suc w) = inj‚ÇÇ (var k -by- w)
                                  --  ‚Ü™ witness
‚ä¢subst
    : ‚àÄ {n} {x y} {Œì : Binder n} {t}
     ‚Üí x ‚â° y
     ‚Üí Œì , x ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù t
     -------------------
     ‚Üí Œì , y ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù t

  ‚ä¢subst {n}{x}{y}{Œì}{t} x‚â°y Œì,x‚ä¢varx‚áùt
   = subst (Œª z ‚Üí Œì , z ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù t) x‚â°y Œì,x‚ä¢varx‚áùt
find-name
    : ‚àÄ {n}
    ‚Üí (Œì : Binder n) ‚Üí (x : Name)
    ------------------------------
    ‚Üí Dec (‚àÉ[ t ] (Œì ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù t))

  -- By induction on the variable context:
  find-name [] x = no helper
    where
      helper : ‚àÑ[ t ] ([] ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù t)
      helper (_ -by- ())

  find-name (y ‚à∑ Œì) x
    with x ‚âü y
  ...  | yes x‚â°y = yes (var (# 0) -by- ‚ä¢subst x‚â°y var-zero)
  ...  | no  x‚â¢y
       with find-name Œì x
          -- case analysis for the output of the recursion
  ...     | yes (lam _ _ -by- ())
  ...     | yes (_ ‚àô _   -by- ())
  ...     | yes (var k -by- Œì‚ä¢x‚áùvark)
            = yes $ var (suc k) -by- var-suc {p = fromWitnessFalse x‚â¢y} Œì‚ä¢x‚áùvark
  ...     | no ‚àÑt‚ü®Œì‚ä¢varx‚áùt‚ü© = no helper
          where
            helper : ‚àÑ[ t ] (Œì , y ‚ä¢ var x ‚áù t)
            helper (t -by- Œì,y‚ä¢varx‚áùt)
              with name-dec Œì,y‚ä¢varx‚áùt
            ...  | inj‚ÇÅ x‚â°y                    = x‚â¢y x‚â°y
            ...  | inj‚ÇÇ p@(t‚Ä≤ -by- Œì‚ä¢varx‚áùt‚Ä≤) = ‚àÑt‚ü®Œì‚ä¢varx‚áùt‚ü© p

We want to determine if given a variable context and a term, it is possible to find its encoding using De Bruijn indexes. If so, we got its respective construction for that lambda term.

check
    : ‚àÄ {n}
    ‚Üí (Œì : Binder n)
    ‚Üí (t : S.Expr)
    ‚Üí Dec (‚àÉ[ t‚Ä≤ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ t ‚áù t‚Ä≤))

  -- By induction on the term syntax.
  check Œì (var x) = find-name Œì x
  check Œì (lam (x ‚à∂ œÑ) t)
    with check (Œì , x) t                          -- TODO: under revision.
  ...  | yes (t‚Ä≤ -by- Œì,x‚ä¢t‚áùt‚Ä≤)
         = yes (lam œÑ t‚Ä≤ -by- lam Œì,x‚ä¢t‚áùt‚Ä≤)
  ...  | no ‚àÑt‚Ä≤‚ü®Œì,x‚ä¢t‚áùt‚Ä≤‚ü© = no helper
       where
         helper : ‚àÑ[ t‚Ä≤ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ lam (x ‚à∂ œÑ) t ‚áù t‚Ä≤)
         helper (var x‚Ä≤ -by- ())
         helper (_ ‚àô _  -by- ())
         helper (lam .œÑ t‚Ä≤ -by- lam Œì,x‚ä¢t‚áùt‚Ä≤)
           = ‚àÑt‚Ä≤‚ü®Œì,x‚ä¢t‚áùt‚Ä≤‚ü© (t‚Ä≤ -by- Œì,x‚ä¢t‚áùt‚Ä≤)

  check Œì (t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ)
    with check Œì t‚ÇÅ | check Œì t‚ÇÇ
  ...  | yes (t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚áùt‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤) | (yes (t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ‚áùt‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤))
         = yes (t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚áùt‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚àô Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ‚áùt‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤)
  ...  | yes (t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚áùt‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤) | (no ‚àÑt‚ü®Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ‚áùt‚ü©) = no helper
       where
         app ≥ : ‚àÄ {n} {Œì : Binder n} {t‚ÇÅ t‚ÇÇ t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤}
              ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚áù t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤
              ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÇ ‚áù t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤
         app ≥ (_ ‚àô Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ‚áùt‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤) = Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ‚áùt‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤

         helper : ‚àÑ[ t ] (Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚áù t)
         helper (var _ -by- ())
         helper (lam _ _ -by- ())
         helper (t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≥ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≥ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚àôt‚ÇÇ‚áùt)
           = ‚àÑt‚ü®Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ‚áùt‚ü© (t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≥ -by- app ≥ Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚àôt‚ÇÇ‚áùt)

  ... | no ‚àÑt‚ü®Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚áùt‚ü©  | _ = no helper
      where
        appÀ° : ‚àÄ {n} {Œì : Binder n} {t‚ÇÅ t‚ÇÇ t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤}
          ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚áù t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤
          ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚áù t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤
        appÀ° (Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚áùt‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚àô _) = Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚áùt‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤

        helper : ‚àÑ[ t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ (t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ) ‚áù t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤)
        helper (var _ -by- ())
        helper (lam _ _ -by- ())
        helper (t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≥ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ‚Ä≥ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚àôt‚ÇÇ‚áùt)
          = ‚àÑt‚ü®Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚áùt‚ü© (t‚ÇÅ‚Ä≥ -by- appÀ° Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ‚àôt‚ÇÇ‚áùt)

  -- Go from a representation that uses Names to one that uses de Bruijn indices
  scope : (t : S.Expr) ‚Üí {p : True (check [] t)} ‚Üí Expr 0
  scope t {p} = proj‚ÇÅ (toWitness p)

Examples

private

  -- postulate
  --   A : Type

  -- I‚ÇÅ : S.Expr
  -- I‚ÇÅ = S.lam ("x" ‚à∂ A) (S.var "x")

  -- open import Data.Unit

  -- I : Expr 0
  -- I = scope I‚ÇÅ {p = ‚ä§.tt}

    postulate A : Type
    x : S.Expr
    x = var "x"

    y : S.Expr
    y = var "y"

    z : S.Expr
    z = var "z"

    S‚ÇÅ : S.Expr
    S‚ÇÅ =
      lam ("x" ‚à∂ A)
        (lam ("y" ‚à∂ A)
        (lam ("z" ‚à∂ A)
        ((x ‚àô z) ‚àô (y ‚àô z))))

    w = check [] S‚ÇÅ
    -- S = scope S‚ÇÅ {p = ‚ä§.tt}

Typing

Type system and its derivation rules.

module Typing (U : Set) where

  data Type : Set where
    base : U    ‚Üí Type
    _‚Ü£_  : Type ‚Üí Type ‚Üí Type

  open Bound Type hiding (_,_)

  open import Data.Nat using (‚Ñï; suc)
  open import Data.Vec using (Vec; _‚à∑_; lookup; [])
  open import Data.Fin using (Fin; #_)


  Ctxt : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Set
  Ctxt = Vec Type

  _,_ : ‚àÄ {n} ‚Üí Ctxt n ‚Üí Type ‚Üí Ctxt (suc n)
  Œì , x = x ‚à∑ Œì

  infixl 20 _,_

  data _‚ä¢_‚à∂_ : ‚àÄ {n} ‚Üí Ctxt n ‚Üí Expr n ‚Üí Type ‚Üí Set where
    tVar : ‚àÄ {n Œì} {x : Fin n}
         ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ var x ‚à∂ lookup x Œì

    tLam : ‚àÄ {n} {Œì : Ctxt n} {t} {œÑ œÑ‚Ä≤}
         ‚Üí Œì , œÑ ‚ä¢ t ‚à∂ œÑ‚Ä≤
         ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ lam œÑ t ‚à∂ œÑ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚Ä≤

    _‚àô_  : ‚àÄ {n} {Œì : Ctxt n} {t‚ÇÅ t‚ÇÇ} {œÑ œÑ‚Ä≤}
         ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚à∂ œÑ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚Ä≤
         ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÇ ‚à∂ œÑ
         ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚à∂ œÑ‚Ä≤

  infixr 30 _‚Ü£_
  infixl 20 _‚àô_
  infixl 20 _‚ä¢_‚à∂_

Examples

private
    postulate
      Bool : Type

    ex : [] , Bool ‚ä¢ var (# 0) ‚à∂ Bool
    ex = tVar

    ex2 : [] ‚ä¢ lam Bool (var (# 0)) ‚à∂ Bool ‚Ü£ Bool
    ex2 = tLam tVar

    postulate
      Word : Type
      Num  : Type

    K : [] ‚ä¢ lam Word (lam Num (var (# 1))) ‚à∂ Word ‚Ü£ Num ‚Ü£ Word
    K = tLam (tLam tVar)

    postulate
      A : Type
      B : Type
      C : Type

    -- S : [] ‚ä¢ lam (A ‚Ü£ (B ‚Ü£ C))
    --              (lam (A ‚Ü£ B)
    --                   (lam A
    --                     ((var (# 2)) ‚àô (var (# 0))) ‚àô ((var (# 1)) ‚àô (var (# 0))) ))
    --        ‚à∂ (A ‚Ü£ (B ‚Ü£ C)) ‚Ü£ (A ‚Ü£ B) ‚Ü£ A ‚Ü£ C
    -- S = tLam (tLam ((tLam ({! tVar  !} ‚àô {!   !})) ‚àô ({! tVar  !} ‚àô {!   !}))) --  tLam (tLam (tLam ((tVar ‚àô tVar) ‚àô (tVar ‚àô tVar))))

Type-checking

module Typecheck {U : Set} (UEq : IsDecEquivalence {A = U} _‚â°_) where

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  open IsDecEquivalence UEq using (_‚âü_)

  open Typing U
    using (Type; base; _‚Ü£_; _‚ä¢_‚à∂_; Ctxt; tVar; tLam; _‚àô_)
  open Bound Type

  open import Data.Nat      hiding (_‚âü_)
  open import Data.Product  hiding (‚àÉ-syntax; ‚àÑ-syntax) renaming (_,_ to _-by-_)
  open import Data.Product  using (‚àÉ; ‚àÑ)
  open import Data.Vec      using (Vec; _‚à∑_; lookup)

  open import Function         using (_‚àò_; _$_)
  open import Relation.Binary.PropositionalEquality
    using (refl; cong; cong‚ÇÇ; sym)
  open import Relation.Nullary using (Dec; yes; no; ¬¨_)

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  -- Equality between Types.
  _T‚âü_ : (œÑ œÑ‚Ä≤ : Type) ‚Üí Dec (œÑ ‚â° œÑ‚Ä≤)

  base A T‚âü base B with A ‚âü B
  ... | yes A‚â°B = yes (cong base A‚â°B)
  ... | no  A‚â¢B = no (A‚â¢B ‚àò helper)
    where
      helper : base A ‚â° base B ‚Üí A ‚â° B
      helper refl = refl
  base A T‚âü (_ ‚Ü£ _) = no (Œª ())

  (œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ) T‚âü base B = no (Œª ())
  (œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ) T‚âü (œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤) with œÑ‚ÇÅ T‚âü œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤
  ... | no  œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â¢œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ = no (œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â¢œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚àò helper)
    where
      helper :  œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ ‚â° œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ ‚Üí œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚â° œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤
      helper refl = refl

  ... | yes œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â°œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ with œÑ‚ÇÇ T‚âü œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤
  ...            | yes œÑ‚ÇÇ‚â°œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ = yes (cong‚ÇÇ _‚Ü£_ œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â°œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ œÑ‚ÇÇ‚â°œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤)
  ...            | no  œÑ‚ÇÇ‚â¢œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ = no (œÑ‚ÇÇ‚â¢œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ ‚àò helper)
    where
      helper : œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ ‚â° œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ ‚Üí œÑ‚ÇÇ ‚â° œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤
      helper refl = refl


  ‚ä¢-inj : ‚àÄ {n Œì} {t : Expr n} ‚Üí ‚àÄ {œÑ œÉ}
        ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t ‚à∂ œÑ
        ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ t ‚à∂ œÉ
        ‚Üí œÑ ‚â° œÉ
  ‚ä¢-inj tVar tVar = refl
  ‚ä¢-inj {t = lam œÑ t} (tLam Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÑ‚Ä≤) (tLam Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÑ‚Ä≥)
    = cong (_‚Ü£_ œÑ) (‚ä¢-inj Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÑ‚Ä≤ Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÑ‚Ä≥)
  ‚ä¢-inj (Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ ‚àô Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ) (Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ü£œÉ ‚àô Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚ÇÅ)
    = helper (‚ä¢-inj Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ü£œÉ)
    where
      helper : ‚àÄ {œÑ œÑ‚ÇÇ œÑ‚ÇÅ œÉ} ‚Üí (œÑ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ ‚â° œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü£ œÉ) ‚Üí œÑ‚ÇÇ ‚â° œÉ
      helper refl = refl

  -- Typability.
  infer : ‚àÄ {n} Œì (t : Expr n) ‚Üí Dec (‚àÉ[ œÑ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ t ‚à∂ œÑ))

  -- Var case.
  infer Œì (var x) = yes (lookup x Œì -by- tVar)

  -- Abstraction case.
  infer Œì (lam œÑ t) with infer (œÑ ‚à∑ Œì) t
  ... | yes (œÉ -by- Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÉ) = yes (œÑ ‚Ü£ œÉ -by- tLam Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÉ)
  ... | no  Œì,œÑ‚ä¨t:œÉ = no helper
    where
      helper : ‚àÑ[ œÑ‚Ä≤ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ lam œÑ t ‚à∂ œÑ‚Ä≤)
      helper (base A -by- ())
      helper (.œÑ ‚Ü£ œÉ -by- tLam Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÉ) = Œì,œÑ‚ä¨t:œÉ (œÉ -by- Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÉ)

  -- Application case.
  infer Œì (t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ) with infer Œì t‚ÇÅ | infer Œì t‚ÇÇ
  ... | no  ‚àÑœÑ‚ü®Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ü© | _ = no helper
      where
        helper : ‚àÑ[ œÉ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚à∂ œÉ)
        helper (œÑ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ ‚àô _) = ‚àÑœÑ‚ü®Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ü© (_ ‚Ü£ œÑ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ)

  ... | yes (base x -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:base) | _ = no helper
      where
        helper : ‚àÑ[ œÉ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚à∂ œÉ)
        helper (œÑ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:_‚Ü£_ ‚àô _)
          with ‚ä¢-inj Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:_‚Ü£_ Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:base
        ...  | ()

  ... | yes (œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ) | no  ‚àÑœÑ‚ü®Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚ü© = no helper
      where
        helper : ‚àÑ[ œÉ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚à∂ œÉ)
        helper (œÑ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ ‚àô Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ)
          with ‚ä¢-inj Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤
        ...  | refl = ‚àÑœÑ‚ü®Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚ü© (œÑ‚ÇÅ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ)

  ... | yes (œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ) | yes (œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤)
      with œÑ‚ÇÅ T‚âü œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤
  ...  | yes œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â°œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ = yes (œÑ‚ÇÇ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ ‚àô helper)
       where
         helper : Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÇ ‚ÄÖ‚à∂ œÑ‚ÇÅ
         helper = subst (_‚ä¢_‚à∂_ Œì t‚ÇÇ) (sym œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â°œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤) Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤
  ...  | no  œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â¢œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ = no helper
       where
         helper : ‚àÑ[ œÉ ] (Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚à∂ œÉ)
         helper (_ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ ‚àô Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚ÇÅ)
           with ‚ä¢-inj  Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ü£œÑ‚ÇÇ
         ...  | refl = œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â¢œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ (‚ä¢-inj Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚ÇÅ Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤)


  -- Type-checking.
  check : ‚àÄ {n} Œì (t : Expr n) ‚Üí ‚àÄ œÑ ‚Üí Dec (Œì ‚ä¢ t ‚à∂ œÑ)

  -- Var case.
  check Œì (var x) œÑ with lookup x Œì T‚âü œÑ
  ... | yes refl = yes tVar
  ... | no ¬¨p    = no (¬¨p ‚àò ‚ä¢-inj tVar)

  -- Abstraction case.
  check Œì (lam œÑ t) (base A) = no (Œª ())
  check Œì (lam œÑ t) (œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ) with œÑ‚ÇÅ T‚âü œÑ
  ... | no œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â¢œÑ = no (œÑ‚ÇÅ‚â¢œÑ ‚àò helper)
      where
        helper : Œì ‚ä¢ lam œÑ t ‚à∂ (œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ) ‚Üí œÑ‚ÇÅ ‚â° œÑ
        helper (tLam t) = refl

  ... | yes refl with check (œÑ ‚à∑ Œì) t œÑ‚ÇÇ
  ...               | yes Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÑ‚ÇÇ = yes (tLam Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:œÑ‚ÇÇ)
  ...               | no  Œì,œÑ‚ä¨t:œÑ‚ÇÇ = no helper
    where
      helper : ¬¨ Œì ‚ä¢ lam œÑ t ‚à∂ œÑ ‚Ü£ œÑ‚ÇÇ
      helper (tLam Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:_) = Œì,œÑ‚ä¨t:œÑ‚ÇÇ Œì,œÑ‚ä¢t:_

  -- Application case.
  check Œì (t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ) œÉ with infer Œì t‚ÇÇ
  ... | yes (œÑ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ)
      with check Œì t‚ÇÅ (œÑ ‚Ü£ œÉ)
  ...    | yes Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚Ü£œÉ = yes (Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚Ü£œÉ ‚àô Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ)
  ...    | no  Œì‚ä¨t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚Ü£œÉ = no helper
    where
      helper : ¬¨ Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚à∂ œÉ
      helper (Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:_‚Ü£_ ‚àô Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚Ä≤)
        with ‚ä¢-inj Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚Ä≤
      ...  | refl = Œì‚ä¨t‚ÇÅ:œÑ‚Ü£œÉ Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÅ:_‚Ü£_

  check Œì (t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ) œÉ | no Œì‚ä¨t‚ÇÇ:_ = no helper
    where
      helper : ¬¨ Œì ‚ä¢ t‚ÇÅ ‚àô t‚ÇÇ ‚à∂ œÉ
      helper (_‚àô_ {œÑ = œÉ} t Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚Ä≤) = Œì‚ä¨t‚ÇÇ:_ (œÉ -by- Œì‚ä¢t‚ÇÇ:œÑ‚Ä≤)

References

  • Barendregt, Henk, Wil Dekkers, and Richard Statman (2013). Lambda calculus with types. Cambridge University Press.
  • Danielsson, Nils Anders. Normalisation for the simply typed lambda calculus.
  • EÃÅrdi, GergoÃã (2013). Simply Typed Lambda Calculus in Agda, Without Shortcuts.
entry.summary: We present a formalisation of the syntax in Agda for the Simple Typed Lambda Calculus (STLC) with some of its properties and the description of the type-checking for this type system. We refactor the implementation by @gergoerdi for this calculus, in particular the Scopecheck and Typecheck module.
